Problem:
Consider a system modeled by the function \\( z(t) = Ce^{i\omega t} \\) which is a complex exponential representing oscillatory behavior with a constant \\( C \\) and angular frequency \\( \omega \). An operator \\( T \\) acts on \\( z(t) \\) as follows: \\( Tz(t) = z(t + h) \\), where \\( h \\) is a time-shift constant.

Can we deduce the original function \\( z(0) \\) after observing \\( z(T) \\) without knowing whether the operator \\( T \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without knowledge of the application of \\( T \\), the unknown shift (or lack thereof) creates ambiguity in determining the original state, as the phase shift introduced by \\( T \\) cannot be distinguished from natural evolution of \\( z(t) \\).

causal_map_integration: Applying the operator T shifts the function z(t) by T units of time, so z(t+T) represents the value of z(t) at a later time.
